Do I like the game? 

Once I've spent ~30 hours modding it, absolutely.

Which is why I can't recommend it. Power creep and capitalism make it very difficult to recommend. The AI out of the box is... Annoying. The AI is not designed to beat you, but to be obstacles for you to overcome. They will all gang up on the player to the point where you're getting attacked from several different angles while ignoring their weaker neghibors. In this way they fail to expand and grow to be a larger threat. As such they never put themselves in a position for victory. The exception of this is those hostiles which are in the FOW. There are other things which appear to be blatant cheating which I only have observation of but not direct proof. Armies spawning where they shouldn't be able to afford anything. AI not managing it's territories/economy. The big thing is the anti player bias and the lack of leathality behind the base AI. 


That being said I have over 600 hours in the game. It's worth the money based on that. However the company which produces it makes you feel like a cow they are milking for currency without a care as to the quality of what they dish out. This is a major problem with the industry as a whole. 

Subsiquent TW games have been horrible cash grabs. This is their current flagship, their last bastion of steady income. It's only a matter of time before it's ruined like HOI4 or Stellaris.

All that said, if you like me, are willing to go through the xml files and completely reballance the game, download thirty or so mods and tinker for as many hours as you play. You may find considerable enjoyment here.

Let's start with the positives. I personally quite enjoy the real time strategy combat between armies and the sandbox campaign. There is also a unique strategic and tactical depth to the game that I'd find other games hard pressed to replicate as well as good level of challenge.

On the negative, it feels like the game suffers from repetitiveness in the later stages of any campaign. I am also not a fan of the Warhammer Fantasy Lore. Furthermore Creative Assemblies monetisation model is not kind to the casual player, requiring you to invest a serious amount of money to get the full use out of each race. 

As such for those looking to buy the game, I can certainly see a world in which it's worth your money but please do regard a buying decision with caution as to enjoy the full experience requires a lot of DLCs and the previous game titles. Sales are your friend in this case. To get a feeling for what the game has to offer I would recommend watching Zerkovich, Legend of Total War and/or Turin.

For a game of this magnitude, there are frankly inexcusable issues that CA simply refuses to fix. This is the third game in the series and has been out for some time, yet basic campaign mechanics literally do not work. 

For example, vassals, especially ones made from minor factions, do not work. They will simply AFK on their main settlement. Additionally, they seem to be largely incapable of winning battles. I once had to reload due to two full stacks of vassals being wiped by an injured tier 1 unit and generic lord. This is made worse by the fact that THERE ARE FACTIONS DESIGNED AROUND VASSALS!!! Chaos is almost unplayable, as they are incentivized to give their stuff to vassals, who will never do anything. Sure, you can try to order them, but 1) it barely works any better than their standard AI. 2) You have to give them orders to attack a specific army or settlement, rather than generic orders or stances such as "be aggressive or defensive". This is only made worse by 3) YOU NEED TO USE A RESOURCE TO ORDER YOUR OWN VASSALS, meaning you are unable to micro them into being useful (not that it would be possible even with unlimited points given how poorly they work). 

Another example is the diplomacy. Want to get a trade agreement with a faction that's not of your race? I hope you're okay with wasting potentially hundreds of thousands of gold to get them to agree. But, if you give them a settlement, no matter how insignificant, they will likely do anything, including become your vassal (for as much good as that will do you). This does not seem to be effected by how much land or armies they have. On top of that the diplomacy is bare bones and hasn't changed functionally from Rome 2.

Lastly, there are antiquated mechanics CA is simply too lazy to update. The biggest thing that comes to mind are rogue armies; full stacks of random, often high tier units (that make 0 sense lore wise; Lizardmen wood elf pirate raiders? Really?) that will wander around your border with impunity until they decide randomly to begin attacking your settlements, often when your armies are on the other side of the map fighting real factions. If you're especially unlucky, they'll attack you early enough in the campaign to essentially make it unplayable, as they start with full, high tier armies for free. 

Bonus: The DLC practice is known to be predatory and excessive. Want the full roster for your favorite faction? I hope your fine with buying 1-2 DLC for it. The worst thing for me is that they only included 1 legendary lord for the demon factions that were new to this game so they could sell you well established and obvious lords like Skulltaker later for a price. 

Battles can be fun but the campaigns range from broken to unplayable. I would encourage anyone to wait for a heavy sale to get into the game.

There are guides out there for how to make targeted purchases for the content pieces you personally care about, and of course you should wait for major sales. Less storage space and still cheaper than actually buying and building/painting in the physical tabletop hobby, though.

Despite the ups and downs that Warhammer III and Creative Assembly on the whole have gone thru over the last couple of years, I think this game is the pinnacle of the Total War series. 

I say this as someone who first got into the series with Medieval Total War (2002) and who put multiple thousands of hours across the 20+ year lifespan of the series. Rome and Medieval 2 were the games I played the most - but this was before I had a business and a family. 

I now have close to 800 hours in WH3, and every time I start a new campaign and get into new faction or lord mechanics, I still often find myself contemplating the journey that starts with the first Medieval (no campaign movement - just hop army token from one province to the next) and ends with WH3, with all the campaign shenannigans, flying unit, lores of magic, etc. 

If you have never played TW Warhammer and find yourself at a loss about where to start, my suggestion is to do a bit of research and find a factions that sounds like it would fit your playstyle, then get yourself all the DLCs that have content for that faction. This will be a portion of the total price tag for all three games and DLCs - and will still give you hundreds of hours of absolutely fantastic gameplay.
